solution.tex: Theorem: a bounded entire function must be constant. In other words, if $f:\mathbb{C}\to\mathbb{C}$ is bounded $(|f(z)|\leq M\forall z\in\mathbb{C})$ and holomorphic then $f$ is constant. Proof: use Cauchy's estimate (just the Cauchy integral formula). Let $z_0\in\mathbb{C}$. We will show $f'(z_0)=0$. This is for all points, so $f$ must then be constant. Let $r>0$ and let $\gamma$ be the boundary of the ball centered at $z_0$ of radius $r$, $\gamma(\theta)=z_0+re^{i\theta}$. Because $f$ is entire, $f$ is holomorphic on the ball. By Cauchy's integral formula (extended version with derivatives), \[f'(z_0)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{(z-z_0)^2}dz.\] Taking absolute value gives \[|f'(z_0)|=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{(z-z_0)^2}dz\right|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\frac{|f(z)|}{|z-z_0|^2}|dz|\] \[=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{|f(z_0+re^{i\theta})|}{|z_0+re^{i\theta}-z_0|^2}|ire^{i\theta}d\theta|=\frac{1}{2\pi r}\int_0^{2\pi}|f(z_0+re^{i\theta})|d\theta.\] By assumption, $|f(z_0+re^{i\theta})|\leq M$, so \[|f'(z_0)|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi r}\int_0^{2\pi}Md\theta=\frac{M}{r}.\] This is true for any $r>0$ because $f$ is entire. Thus $|f'(z_0)|\leq0$, so $f'=0$ as claimed.
